data.title: new tab position depends on active tab
data.body:
v1.11.0-insider

If I have two files 'pinned' open (keep open), when I open a third:
- new file opens on **end** if I got second file active
- new file opens **in between** two pinned files if first is active

I am not sure if working as intended?
but would anyone else appreciate an option to make new tab position independent of active tab?
Thanks.

`  "workbench.editor.newTabs": right|left|active,`

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12622

data.title: Elixir.tmLanguage works in Sublime but fails in VSCode
data.body: When using the official Elixir.tmLanguage file found [here](https://github.com/elixir-lang/elixir-tmbundle/blob/master/Syntaxes/Elixir.tmLanguage), lines that begin with a whitespace character or an arbitrary unhighlighted token (e.g. `foo`) are not highlighted (see screenshot below). The Elixir.tmLanguage file does—of course—work perfectly fine in TextMate and Sublime. https://github.com/elixir-lang/elixir-tmbundle/blob/master/Syntaxes/Elixir.tmLanguage - VSCode Version: 1.10.2 - OS Version: macOS 10.12.3 (Sierra)

data.title: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat ' '
Override git global username & email in both User Settings & Workspace Settings
data.body:
> It's a feature request to override the username / email in commits made from VS Code. This could help people with more than one account (personal & work) to well manage the author in the commits.

## Problem:
People using work laptops are likely to have their global email configured to work email. They might use full blown Visual Studio IDE for work but VS Code for personal projects. But, when using VS Code for personal projects on the same machine commits always take the work email. There's currently no way to customize the username / email used in commits made from VS Code.

## Proposed Solution:
We can configure the username / email for a specific repository (Workspace Settings) or for entire VS Code (User Settings).

The configuration could be something like

```json
"git.username": "Rohith Kumbharkar",
"git.email": "rohithkumbharkar@users.noreply.github.com"
```

The order of preference would be

1. Workspace settings
2. User settings
3. git globals

Before making a commit, VS Code will look for **git.username** & **git.email** in Workspace then User settings.

If the values are not found in both Workspace & User settings then it reverts back to default behavior of fetching from git global config.

data.title: Possible feature request: Edit parts of a file as if they are separate files accessible by tabs.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
edit: if this already exists, could you please tell me what the setting is called.

I'm not sure if there is a reason this is not in practice/common place.

Say it was a JavaScript file and you had three functions, function one(), function two(), function three()...

If you had three separate files open, you'd have three tabs that you can click on and switch between the files.

If you had a pretty complex JavaScript file and wanted to 'chunk it' and modify it as if it was made of multiple individual files, while keeping it as one... I achieved this effect by using the small-scripts approach where you then had to include each one sequentially on an html page to work in order.

Yeah this might be a pointless question, how would you even activate that/specify where the splits happen? Highligh/select a section/code block?

data.title: Incorrect background color for themes on insiders build
data.body:
Hello,

The background color for some themes don't seem to be showing correctly.

Consider the screenshot shown on this [theme](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=sharksym.theme-cobalt0):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8539864/23827537/0e603746-0684-11e7-94b0-2cb09bc6403e.png)

VSCode insiders after installing and selecting theme: 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8539864/23827545/34fc1708-0684-11e7-93e2-02104ae18788.png)

It seems to be working fine on the non-insider version, though: 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8539864/23827588/d2835432-0684-11e7-9a2f-14404229de3a.png)

I've tried disabling all extensions and enabling only desired themes to make sure no extensions are messing with it, as well as adjusting the background color in the .tmTheme of individual themes themselves, but neither helped.

data.title: Use link cursor instead of select for details section in Markdown preview
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows7 x64.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add a `detail` section in markdown (.md) document

```
<details>
  <summary>Source Code</summary>
   
   Some text
</details>
```

2. Open Preview: ![details-section](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1150330/23827173/56054926-06be-11e7-9a86-3c7dd6ddd106.png)
For this element a `link` cursor ![link](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1150330/23827148/daaca094-06bd-11e7-895b-07ee2961a81f.png) should be used (same for common links) instead of `select` cursor ![select](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1150330/23827151/e172e8b6-06bd-11e7-9ce1-e54aa2c273e7.png).

data.title: Don't update disabled extensions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
There seems to be a functional difference installed extensions disabled on a workspace level (they show up in settings). In the case of an extension disabled through the UI, I don't need it kept up-to-date until it's re-enableld through the UI. 

As of now, when an extension is disabled it still gets counted in the sidebar number for "extensions waiting to update". If I've disabled an extension, it would be nice if it's out of sight, out of mind.

- VSCode Version: `Version 1.10.2 (1.10.2)`
- OS Version: macOS `10.12.2`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install any extension
2. Hit `Disable` in the extensions panel
3. Wait for extension to update
4. Extension is shown as both disabled, and needing an update. There's a blue number shown in the sidebar for a disabled extension.

data.title: Refactor to fix compile error with noImplicitAny
data.body:
Some refactorings

- Introduced index signature.
- Fixed to use ES6 Map properly.
- Fixed type signature.
- Fixed to use `foo.bar` instead of `foo[bar]`

All of these changes fix compile errors which occur if `noImplicitAny` in `tsconfig.json` is set to `true`.

data.title: Markdown preview window shrinks when zooming in with 'Cmd + ='.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

I've tested it on a fresh VM. No extensions were installed.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. make a .md file.
2. 'Shift + Cmd + v' to preview markdown file.
3. Hit 'Cmd + =' several times to zoom in. Following screenshots show the window shrinking problem:

![screen_shot_00](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13075164/23826424/2a705f8c-06df-11e7-82b2-3bcd9ba4b307.png)
![screen_shot_01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13075164/23826426/335282ec-06df-11e7-91b1-1ace01a56319.png)
![screen_shot_02](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13075164/23826428/3a4f6a10-06df-11e7-8f1b-2cceb86ab78d.png)

I've found a similar issue on the StackOverflow: <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42172373/when-the-zoom-increses-ctrl-the-markdown-preview-width-shrinks>

But, the answer on the issue does not solve the problem.

data.title: jsdoc auto-insert parameter names and render HTML
data.body:
Great feature auto-jsdoc!!!

Is there a reason not to put in the parameter types, if present?  Including {parameter-type} before the parameter name leads to clearer highlighting of the parameter name.

Also, HTML within the jsdoc comments is reproduced plain text.  Is there a plan to render the HTML?

Thanks!

Steve

data.title: window.showQuickPick doesn't return when cancelled (esc key) with a long running items promise
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (01091bb0831f7ce07db3cdc3ad66abb4141ffd8d, 2017-03-10T07:05:03.565Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Provide a long running (or infinite) promise to `window.showQuickPick`
2. See the quick pick with the progress indication
3. Press `esc` to cancel the quick pick
4. Visibly the quick pick goes away, but `window.showQuickPick` doesn't return
5. Expected that `window.showQuickPick` would return as soon as it was cancelled

Also if you provide an infinite promise (never resolves) `window.showQuickPick` never returns at all not matter what happens next (other quick picks are shown, etc)

data.title: Feature Request: Language support for Objective-C, Objective-C++ and Swift
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Go to a Swift file, Objective-C file or Objective-C++ file.
2. Go Menu -> Go to Symbol in File

Result:
No symbols in the file

Expect:
The languages that everyone builds Apps in for iOS and macOS to be supported.

This is a really cool editor, but the lack of native language support is a deal breaker.

data.title: Add option to follow the last valid active path for untitled editors outside of a workspace

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This PR adds an option to store the last active valid path when switching editors to use the path directory as the base directory for saving untitled editors when creating new files outside of a workspace. This is a feature that Sublime Text provides out of the box and I made a huge habit of (ab)using it so I figured I might as well give it a try to implement it in vscode.

If such feature either already exists and I missed it or is unwanted then feel free to ignore it.

Assuming the following three editor tabs open and the feature option set to ON:
1) /home/user/dir1/a.txt
2) /home/user/dir2/b.txt
3) Untitled-1

The feature will provide the following behavior:
* If we switch to tab 1), then 3), and then attempt to save the untitled editor, the file dialog will use /home/user/dir1/ as the base directory.
* If we switch to tab 2), then 3), and then attempt to save the untitled editor, the file dialog will use /home/user/dir2/ as the base directory.
* And so on...

The feature needs to be enabled explicitly and the old behavior is retained by default.
